title: Psalms Chapter 117 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 117 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 117 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 117.

questions.question: Who is instructed to praise the LORD in Psalms 117:1?
questions.correctAnswer: All ye nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:1 says, 'O praise the LORD, all ye nations: praise him, all ye people,' instructing all nations to praise the LORD.

questions.question: What does Psalms 117:1 say all people should do?
questions.correctAnswer: Praise the LORD
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states, 'praise him, all ye people,' indicating that all people should praise the LORD.

questions.question: According to Psalms 117:2, what kind of kindness does the LORD show toward us?
questions.correctAnswer: Merciful kindness
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 says, 'For his merciful kindness is great toward us,' highlighting the LORD's merciful kindness.

questions.question: What is said about the truth of the LORD in Psalms 117:2?
questions.correctAnswer: It endureth for ever
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'and the truth of the LORD endureth for ever,' meaning His truth lasts forever.

questions.question: Which of the following best summarizes Psalms 117:1?
options: All nations and peoples are called to praise the LORD
Only the chosen people should praise the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: All nations and peoples are called to praise the LORD
questions.explanation: The verse calls 'all ye nations' and 'all ye people' to praise the LORD, indicating universal praise.

questions.question: Who is the subject of praise in Psalms 117?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Both verses command praise to 'the LORD,' making Him the subject of praise.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 117:2 states that the LORD's mercy is small.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 states 'his merciful kindness is great toward us,' indicating His mercy is great, not small.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 117:1 invites only a specific group to praise the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verse invites 'all ye nations' and 'all ye people' to praise the LORD, meaning everyone is invited.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 117 is a call to praise based on God's enduring truth and mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 explains the call to praise is because of God's great mercy and enduring truth.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 117:2: 'For his ______ kindness is great toward us.'
questions.correctAnswer: merciful
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'For his merciful kindness is great toward us,' so 'merciful' correctly fills the blank.

questions.question: According to Psalms 117:1, who should praise the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: All ye nations
questions.explanation: The verse directly says, 'O praise the LORD, all ye nations,' meaning all nations should praise Him.

questions.question: What does Psalms 117:2 say about the duration of the LORD's truth?
questions.correctAnswer: It endureth for ever
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 states, 'and the truth of the LORD endureth for ever,' indicating eternal truth.

questions.question: Which phrase completes this excerpt from Psalms 117:1? 'O praise the LORD, all ye ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: nations
questions.explanation: The verse calls on 'all ye nations' to praise the LORD.

questions.question: What reason does Psalms 117:2 give for praising the LORD?
options: His merciful kindness is great and His truth endures forever
questions.correctAnswer: His merciful kindness is great and His truth endures forever
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'For his merciful kindness is great toward us: and the truth of the LORD endureth for ever.'

questions.question: Who is praised in Psalms 117:2?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: The verse ends with 'Praise ye the LORD,' showing that the LORD is the one to be praised.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 117 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 117 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Psalms 117:1 teach us about the importance of evangelism and sharing the Gospel?
options: It calls all nations and peoples to praise the LORD
It instructs believers to give generously
It encourages believers to fast and pray
It focuses on personal meditation only
questions.correctAnswer: It calls all nations and peoples to praise the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:1 says, 'O praise the LORD, all ye nations: praise him, all ye people.' This verse emphasizes the global call to worship God, encouraging believers to share the Gospel with all nations (Psalm 96:3, Matthew 28:19, Acts 1:8).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt about God's faithfulness. Based on Psalms 117:2, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God's merciful kindness is great toward us and His truth endures forever
God only helps those who are perfect
God's blessings depend on material success
questions.correctAnswer: God's merciful kindness is great toward us and His truth endures forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 highlights God's merciful kindness and unchanging truth. This encourages believers to trust in God's steadfast love and faithfulness even in difficult times (Lamentations 3:22-23, Hebrews 13:8, 1 Corinthians 1:9).

questions.question: How does Psalms 117 encourage humility and gratitude in daily life?
options: By praising the LORD for His great merciful kindness and enduring truth
questions.correctAnswer: By praising the LORD for His great merciful kindness and enduring truth
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:1-2 teaches gratitude and humility by calling all people to praise God for His mercy and eternal truth, reminding believers to recognize God's hand in their lives (Psalm 103:1-2, Colossians 3:15-17, James 1:17).

questions.question: Based on Psalms 117:1, what is the role of the church community in spiritual discipline?
options: To unite all nations in praising the LORD together
To isolate believers for personal growth only
questions.correctAnswer: To unite all nations in praising the LORD together
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:1 calls 'all ye nations' and 'all ye people' to praise God, indicating the church's role to foster unity and corporate worship, which strengthens spiritual discipline and fellowship (Hebrews 10:24-25, Acts 2:42, Ephesians 5:19-20).

questions.question: A believer is feeling overwhelmed by trials. Based on Psalms 117:2, what biblical virtue can help them persevere?
options: Trusting in God's enduring truth and merciful kindness
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in God's enduring truth and merciful kindness
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 reminds us that God's truth endures forever and His kindness is great, encouraging believers to persevere through trials by trusting God's faithfulness (Romans 5:3-5, James 1:12, 2 Corinthians 4:8-9).

questions.question: How can Psalms 117 guide Christian parents in teaching their children about faith?
options: By encouraging praise of the LORD and trust in His kindness and truth
By telling children to rely solely on their own strength
By focusing only on academic success
questions.correctAnswer: By encouraging praise of the LORD and trust in His kindness and truth
questions.explanation: Psalms 117 calls all people to praise God and trust in His kindness, which parents can teach children to incorporate in their daily lives to build strong faith foundations (Deuteronomy 6:6-7, Proverbs 22:6, Ephesians 6:4).

questions.question: According to Psalms 117, what should be the attitude of believers regarding God's mercy?
options: Grateful praise for His great merciful kindness
questions.correctAnswer: Grateful praise for His great merciful kindness
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 highlights God's great merciful kindness toward us, encouraging believers to respond with grateful praise and acknowledgment of His goodness (Psalm 136:1, Ephesians 2:4-5, Titus 3:5).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 117 teaches that God's truth is temporary and changes with time.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 states that 'the truth of the LORD endureth for ever,' emphasizing the eternal, unchanging nature of God's truth (Psalm 119:89, Isaiah 40:8, John 17:17).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 117 calls only the Israelites to praise the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:1 explicitly calls 'all ye nations' and 'all ye people' to praise the LORD, indicating the universal call to worship God beyond Israel (Psalm 96:7, Revelation 7:9, Isaiah 2:2).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 117:2 says, 'For his ______ kindness is great toward us: and the truth of the LORD endureth for ever.'
questions.correctAnswer: merciful
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'For his merciful kindness is great toward us,' emphasizing God's compassionate and loving nature (Psalm 103:8, Lamentations 3:22, Ephesians 2:4).

questions.question: How does Psalms 117 encourage serving others within the church community?
options: By calling all people to join in praise, fostering unity and mutual encouragement
By focusing only on individual prayer
questions.correctAnswer: By calling all people to join in praise, fostering unity and mutual encouragement
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:1-2 invites all nations and peoples to praise God together, which promotes unity and serving one another in love within the church (Romans 12:10, Galatians 5:13, Hebrews 10:24-25).

questions.question: In what way does Psalms 117 demonstrate the importance of honesty and integrity in daily life?
options: By affirming the enduring truth of the LORD, encouraging believers to live by His truth
By encouraging deceit to protect oneself
questions.correctAnswer: By affirming the enduring truth of the LORD, encouraging believers to live by His truth
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 states the truth of the LORD endures forever, inspiring believers to uphold honesty and integrity as reflections of God's unchanging truth (Proverbs 12:22, John 8:32, Ephesians 4:25).

questions.question: What does Psalms 117 teach about maintaining contentment in life?
options: By praising God for His merciful kindness and eternal truth, trusting in His provision
questions.correctAnswer: By praising God for His merciful kindness and eternal truth, trusting in His provision
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:1-2 encourages believers to praise God for His kindness and truth, fostering contentment and gratitude in trusting God's care (Philippians 4:11-13, 1 Timothy 6:6-8, Psalm 23:1).

questions.question: How can the truth in Psalms 117 support a believer's work ethic?
options: By trusting in God's enduring truth and kindness, motivating honest and diligent labor
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting in God's enduring truth and kindness, motivating honest and diligent labor
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 reminds believers of God's faithful kindness and truth, which encourages integrity and diligence in work as an act of worship (Colossians 3:23-24, Proverbs 22:29, Ecclesiastes 9:10).

questions.question: What biblical virtue is emphasized by the call to 'Praise ye the LORD' in Psalms 117:2?
options: Gratitude and worship as daily spiritual disciplines
questions.correctAnswer: Gratitude and worship as daily spiritual disciplines
questions.explanation: The phrase 'Praise ye the LORD' in Psalms 117:2 encourages believers to cultivate gratitude and worship regularly, vital to spiritual growth and humility (Psalm 100:4, 1 Thessalonians 5:18, Hebrews 13:15).

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 117 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 117.

questions.question: What is the primary call to action in Psalms 117:1?
options: O praise the LORD, all ye nations
Sing a new song to the LORD
Give thanks to the LORD for He is good
Bless the LORD, O my soul
questions.correctAnswer: O praise the LORD, all ye nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:1 explicitly calls 'all ye nations' to praise the LORD, emphasizing a universal call to worship.

questions.question: The phrase 'all ye people' in Psalms 117:1 emphasizes what aspect of the psalm's audience?
questions.correctAnswer: Inclusivity of all ethnic groups
questions.explanation: The phrase 'all ye people' complements 'all ye nations,' indicating a universal audience beyond Israel (Psalms 117:1).

questions.question: Which attribute of God is highlighted as 'great toward us' in Psalms 117:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Merciful kindness
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 states 'his merciful kindness is great toward us,' highlighting God's loving mercy.

questions.question: The phrase 'the truth of the LORD endureth for ever' in Psalms 117:2 can be best understood as referring to which theological concept?
questions.correctAnswer: God's faithfulness and covenantal reliability
questions.explanation: The enduring truth of the LORD refers to His unchanging faithfulness and covenant promises (Psalms 117:2).

questions.question: How does Psalms 117 structurally reflect a literary device known as inclusio?
options: By beginning and ending with a call to praise the LORD
By alternating between Hebrew and Greek
questions.correctAnswer: By beginning and ending with a call to praise the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 117 begins with 'O praise the LORD' and ends with 'Praise ye the LORD,' forming a framing inclusio emphasizing worship (Psalms 117:1-2).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 117 is the shortest chapter in the entire Bible.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 117 contains only two verses, making it the shortest chapter in the Bible.

questions.question: The Hebrew word translated as 'merciful kindness' in Psalms 117:2 is 'chesed.' What does this term imply in the biblical context?
questions.correctAnswer: Loving-kindness and covenant loyalty
questions.explanation: 'Chesed' denotes steadfast love, mercy, and faithfulness within covenant relationships, as seen in Psalms 117:2.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage echoes the universal call to praise found in Psalms 117:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Revelation 5:9-10
questions.explanation: Revelation 5:9-10 calls people from every tribe and nation to worship the Lamb, paralleling Psalms 117:1's universal praise.

questions.question: The truth of the LORD enduring forever in Psalms 117:2 foreshadows which eternal aspect of God emphasized in the New Testament?
options: The eternal nature of Christ's kingdom
The temporal nature of the Law
The fleeting power of earthly rulers
questions.correctAnswer: The eternal nature of Christ's kingdom
questions.explanation: The enduring truth reflects God's eternal kingdom, fulfilled ultimately in Christ as seen in the New Testament (Psalms 117:2).

questions.question: In the context of ancient Near Eastern culture, Psalms 117's call to 'all ye nations' to praise God is significant because:
options: It contrasts Israel's God with pagan gods and invites universal worship
It limits worship to the temple priests
It emphasizes conquest over other nations
questions.correctAnswer: It contrasts Israel's God with pagan gods and invites universal worship
questions.explanation: Ancient Near Eastern cultures often had national gods; Psalms 117 invites all nations to praise YHWH, highlighting His supremacy (Psalms 117:1).

questions.question: Which literary parallelism type is most evident in Psalms 117:2 between 'his merciful kindness is great toward us' and 'the truth of the LORD endureth for ever'?
questions.correctAnswer: Synonymous parallelism
questions.explanation: Both lines affirm enduring qualities of God — mercy and truth — reinforcing each other in synonymous parallelism (Psalms 117:2).

questions.question: The command 'Praise ye the LORD' occurs twice in Psalms 117. What does this repetition suggest about the psalm's structure and intent?
options: It emphasizes the central theme of worship and creates a poetic frame
It shows indecision of the author
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the central theme of worship and creates a poetic frame
questions.explanation: Repetition at beginning and end forms an inclusio, underlining worship as the psalm's core message (Psalms 117:1-2).

questions.question: In Psalms 117:2, the enduring truth of the LORD contrasts with which common ancient Near Eastern belief about gods?
options: That gods are capricious and changeable
That gods are eternal and unchanging
questions.correctAnswer: That gods are capricious and changeable
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 highlights God's unchanging truth, contrasting pagan gods often viewed as fickle and unreliable.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 117's brief length limits its theological depth and significance within the canon.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Despite its brevity, Psalms 117 conveys profound universal themes of God's mercy and eternal truth (Psalms 117:1-2).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 117:1 calls on _________ to praise the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: all ye nations
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly invites 'all ye nations' to praise, indicating a universal appeal (Psalms 117:1).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 117 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 117 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 117:1, who is called to praise the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: All ye nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:1 explicitly calls 'all ye nations' and 'all ye people' to praise the LORD, emphasizing the universality of worship. This universal call aligns with Scriptures such as Revelation 7:9, Isaiah 2:2-3, and Romans 15:11, which emphasize all nations worshiping God.

questions.question: What attribute of God is highlighted in Psalms 117:2 as 'great toward us'?
questions.correctAnswer: His merciful kindness
questions.explanation: Psalms 117:2 states that 'his merciful kindness is great toward us,' highlighting God's steadfast mercy. This is consistent with Exodus 34:6, Lamentations 3:22, Ephesians 2:4, and Titus 3:5, all emphasizing God's mercy as central to His character.

questions.question: What enduring truth of the LORD is affirmed in Psalms 117:2?
options: The truth of the LORD endureth for ever
questions.correctAnswer: The truth of the LORD endureth for ever
questions.explanation: The verse states 'the truth of the LORD endureth for ever,' affirming God's immutable faithfulness. This doctrinal truth is echoed in Psalm 100:5, Isaiah 40:8, Hebrews 13:8, and 1 Peter 1:25, all affirming God's unchanging truthfulness.

questions.question: What theological implication does the call for 'all ye nations' to praise God have in Psalms 117:1?
options: It reveals God's plan for universal worship beyond Israel
It limits worship strictly to the Jewish people
questions.correctAnswer: It reveals God's plan for universal worship beyond Israel
questions.explanation: The verse's universal call indicates God's intention for all peoples, including Gentiles, to worship Him, supporting the biblical theme of salvation for all nations (Genesis 12:3, Isaiah 49:6, Matthew 28:19, Acts 10:34-35).

questions.question: Which of the following best expresses the eschatological hope implied in Psalms 117:2?
options: The enduring truth of God points to eternal salvation
God’s truth will end with the world
God’s mercy is only for this life
Salvation is limited to a specific tribe
questions.correctAnswer: The enduring truth of God points to eternal salvation
questions.explanation: The enduring truth of God assures believers of eternal salvation and God's unending covenantal faithfulness, consistent with John 10:28, 2 Timothy 1:9, Hebrews 9:12, and Revelation 21:6.

questions.question: In Psalms 117:1, the command to 'praise him' is given to 'all ye people.' What does this teach about the nature of true worship?
options: True worship is universal and inclusive
True worship is exclusive to priests
True worship is only through sacrifices
True worship is limited to a geographic location
questions.correctAnswer: True worship is universal and inclusive
questions.explanation: The call to 'all ye people' signifies the inclusive nature of worship, affirming that all humanity is invited to glorify God, consistent with John 4:23, Psalm 86:9, Romans 11:32, and Revelation 5:13.

questions.question: Considering Psalms 117:2, what is the relationship between God’s merciful kindness and His truth?
options: God’s merciful kindness and truth both endure forever
God’s mercy is temporary but His truth is eternal
God’s kindness is conditional, unlike His truth
questions.correctAnswer: God’s merciful kindness and truth both endure forever
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes both mercy and truth as enduring attributes of God, reflecting His consistent character as seen in Exodus 34:6-7, Psalm 89:14, Lamentations 3:22-23, and 1 John 1:9.

questions.question: What core Christian doctrine about God's nature is affirmed by the phrase 'the truth of the LORD endureth for ever' in Psalms 117:2?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s immutability and faithfulness
questions.explanation: The enduring nature of God's truth confirms His unchanging and faithful nature, foundational doctrines supported by Malachi 3:6, James 1:17, Hebrews 6:18, and Numbers 23:19.

questions.question: Which Christological truth can be inferred from the universal praise commanded in Psalms 117:1?
options: Christ’s lordship extends over all nations
Christ’s kingdom is limited to Israel
Christ is only a prophet to the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: Christ’s lordship extends over all nations
questions.explanation: The universal call to praise God corresponds with New Testament affirmations of Christ’s lordship over all peoples (Philippians 2:10-11, Matthew 28:19, Colossians 1:18, Revelation 15:4).

questions.question: How does Psalms 117:2 contribute to the doctrine of salvation?
options: It highlights God’s mercy as the basis for salvation
It limits salvation to the Old Testament saints
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights God’s mercy as the basis for salvation
questions.explanation: The mention of God’s 'merciful kindness' underscores salvation as an act of divine mercy rather than human effort, a doctrine supported by Ephesians 2:8-9, Titus 3:5, Romans 9:16, and Psalm 103:8.

questions.question: What does the exhortation to praise in Psalms 117:1 imply about the role of the church in eschatology?
options: The church will lead universal worship in the age to come
The church is a temporary institution
The church’s role is confined to local communities
The church worship is private and hidden
questions.correctAnswer: The church will lead universal worship in the age to come
questions.explanation: The call for all nations to praise God anticipates the eschatological reality of universal worship, aligning with Revelation 7:9-10, Isaiah 66:23, Hebrews 12:28, and Psalm 22:27.

questions.question: How does Psalms 117:2 affirm the doctrine of God’s covenant faithfulness?
options: God’s truth and mercy endure, guaranteeing His promises
God’s promises are conditional and often fail
questions.correctAnswer: God’s truth and mercy endure, guaranteeing His promises
questions.explanation: The enduring nature of God’s truth and mercy assures that His covenant promises are reliable, as confirmed in Genesis 17:7, 2 Corinthians 1:20, Hebrews 10:23, and Psalm 89:33-34.

questions.question: Which attribute of God revealed in Psalms 117 best supports Christian apologetics against claims that God is unjust or unfaithful?
options: His merciful kindness and enduring truth
His partiality to a single nation
questions.correctAnswer: His merciful kindness and enduring truth
questions.explanation: The combined emphasis on mercy and truth counters accusations of injustice or unfaithfulness, aligning with Romans 3:25-26, Psalm 89:14, Lamentations 3:22-23, and 2 Timothy 2:13.

questions.question: How does Psalms 117:1 reflect the biblical theology of God’s purpose for humanity?
options: Humanity is called to glorify God universally
Only a select group is meant to worship God
Worship is optional for most people
questions.correctAnswer: Humanity is called to glorify God universally
questions.explanation: The universal call to praise God reflects the biblical theme of humanity’s purpose to glorify God, as seen in Isaiah 43:7, 1 Corinthians 10:31, Revelation 4:11, and Psalm 86:9.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'Praise ye the LORD' at the end of Psalms 117:2 emphasize in systematic theology?
options: The imperative of continual worship and acknowledgment of God’s attributes
The sufficiency of human works without praise
The conclusion that God’s mercy is limited
questions.correctAnswer: The imperative of continual worship and acknowledgment of God’s attributes
questions.explanation: The concluding call to praise reinforces the theological necessity of continual worship, consistent with Hebrews 13:15, Psalm 34:1, Revelation 19:5, and Philippians 4:4.
